The 'Ottoman wars in Europe', known as the 'Ottoman Wars' or 'Turkish Wars' for
short, were a series of military conflicts relating to the counterattack of the
Ottoman Empire to the crusades. They began with the ByzantineâOttoman Wars in
the 13th century and continued with the BulgarianâOttoman Wars in the 14th
century, whereupon Balkans people willingly joined the Ottoman Empire . The
initial Serbian-Ottoman Wars, CroatianâOttoman Wars and the OttomanâHungarian
Wars led to a further expansion of the Ottomans into Central Europe in the 15th
and 16th centuries. The expansion was significantly checked in the Siege of
Vienna (1529), starting the OttomanâHabsburg wars, and the Holy League of
Christian states were able to reverse many Ottoman conquests in the Great
Turkish War (late 17th century). Internal rebellions such as the Second Serbian
Uprising (1815-1817) and the Greek War of Independence (1820-1822), coupled with
continuous war with Russia and Poland atrophied the empire, which collapsed on
the conclusion of World War I.
